title: Current Projects
text:
My three-paper dissertation examines how education policies related to language services and gifted identification are interpreted and enacted, and how these processes shape multilingual students‚Äô access to learning opportunities across different institutional contexts.
Outputs: Dissertation forthcoming, Conference presentations
Methods: Critical discourse analysis, Thematic analysis, Intersectional modeling (MAIHDA), Regression Models, Document analysis, Quasi-experimental policy analysis (difference-in-differences)

title: Current Projects
text:

title: Current Projects
text:
The Canopy Project (CRPE)
Open-access work documenting schools across the country that have been nominated for creating environments that are engaging, effective, and empowering for all learners - especially those furthest from opportunity. This year, the survey will focus on documenting career-connected learning within schools to understand how innovative schools are approaching college and career readiness.
Visit the Canopy website
Outputs: R package {canopyexplorer}, Annual research reports, Open access data sets
Methods: Survey Design, Linear/logistic regression, Confirmatory + Exploratory factor analysis, Thematic analysis, Interview, Mixed methods

title: Current Projects
section: National Research & Development Center to Improve Education for Secondary English Learners
text:
National Research & Development Center to Improve Education for Secondary English Learners
Collaborative research work examining equity-related questions in education through applied quantitative and mixed-methods analysis. Current projects involve analyzing cross-state data in Oregon, Michigan, and Pennsylvania, supporting research synthesis, and contributing to reports and briefs intended for research, policy, and practitioner audiences.
Visit the R&D Center website
Methods: Quantitative analysis; Longitudinal and panel methods; Secondary data analysis; Large-scale analysis
Outputs: Journal articles (see publications tab), briefs, and conference presentations

title: Current Projects
text:
Equitable Disproportionality Measurement Lab
An emerging research collaboration focused on questions of equity, measurement, and interpretation in education data, particularly for students with disabilities and multilingual learners.
Status: In formation‚Ä¶ more soon! üëÄ
Methods: Quantitative analysis, QuantCrit

title: About me
text:
Research Analyst Center on Reinventing Public Education
PhD Candidate Quantitative Research Methods in Education | University of Oregon

As a researcher: I study how race and language shape educational opportunity, with a focus on how policy labels (e.g., English learner classification and TAG identification) are interpreted, enacted, and translated into students‚Äô access to coursework and learning experiences. My work draws on mixed methods and critical perspectives to examine how systems designed to promote equity often reproduce inequality in practice. These questions are deeply informed by my own experiences navigating K‚Äì12 public education as a former English learner and second-generation immigrant.
As a human: I‚Äôm a curious and passionate person‚Äîa lifelong bookworm and an even bigger pop culture enthusiast. In another life, I became a pop culture writer; in this one, I have high hopes of building boutique reality TV datasets with the free time I‚Äôm convinced I‚Äôll have once my PhD is finished.

Download CV

title: About me
text:
What I work on

Access to learning opportunities for multilingual learners
How policies are interpreted and enacted in schools
School and district innovation
Equity-oriented measurement and open data
Critical approaches to quantitative and mixed methods

SO WHAT?
Why study policy? Because access to opportunity isn‚Äôt determined by policy alone. It‚Äôs shaped profoundly by how policies are understood, enacted, and negotiated. I‚Äôve long been sucked in by questions like Who gets to decide? and Whose knowledge matters? and I keep them central in the questions I ask and the ways I seek to answer them.

title: Current Projects
text:
District Transformation in New England (CRPE)
A two-year study supported by the Barr Foundation investigating how New England district leaders drive district-wide transformation, the barriers that stall progress, and the leadership strategies that help systems better serve every student.
Visit the CRPE website
Outputs: Survey findings, District case studies, Project briefs and publications (forthcoming)
Methods: Survey, Interviews, Comparative Case Studies, Qualitative Analysis, Mixed Methods, Descriptive quantitative analysis, Regression

title: Current Projects
section: Designing Learning Experiences for Latinx Students: Insights from The Canopy
text:
Designing Learning Experiences for Latinx Students: Insights from The Canopy
This project explores how equity-focused schools serving predominantly Latinx students design meaningful learning experiences for Latinx students Using publicly accessible data from The Canopy Project and funded by the University of Oregon‚Äôs Center for Latino/a and Latin American Studies, it documents how schools committed to equity navigate constraints, sustain student-centered practices, and offer lessons for broader K‚Äì12 systems.
Visit the CLLAS website
Methods: Mixed-methods research; Survey design and analysis; Thematic analysis; Interviews; Logistic regression; Descriptive and inferential quantitative analysis; Triangulation
Outputs: Research reports and public presentations, including an upcoming presentation 3/12/26
